description.text:
I really like AnotherFilamentSpoolHolder by TheKre8Group but the Hatchbox spools fit loosely on the spine. This modified spline design takes up the slack and securely holds the filament spool to the spine. The insert was designed for the Hatchbox spools I have therefore check your spool dimensions before printing. If using with other filament brands, only the insert needs to be redesigned. I have Included all part files and two drawing files for aid in the design of additional inserts.

You will need to print:
1 x spoolholder_base
1 x spoolholder_screw_spine_1
1 x spoolholder_screw_spine_2
2 x spoolholder_insert_HatchboxPLA
2 x spoolholder_clip

title: 2017 Christmas Picture Ornament w/ Santa Hat

description.text:
2017 Christmas Ornament

Print the 2017 part in white and the hat in red. The hat snaps on. The ring is a template for cutting out the picture and snaps in the back to hold the picture in place. There are holes in the back for a string or hook to hang on the tree.

The hat and ring I printed with 0 infill but the 2017 part needs about 20%.

I have printed a few of these already and 80% scale seems to be as small as you can go before the zero starts to fail.

Let me know if you want a name added to the hat. I can customize the model for you and as a bonus, I give you permission to get yourself something nice for the holidays.

title: Adoptabot V1.2 Modified for Ramps and E3D V6

description.text:
Adoptabot.

Ramps & E3D variant for Adoptabot

Bobblejot Website

Bobblejot GitHub

Bobblejot Twitter

This is a variation of the Adoptabot by Printrbot. Being in the UK some parts are easier to get than others so i have modified the brilliant little adoptabot by Brook to use easily available Ramps and E3D parts.

I have also added a cover for the Ramps board as well as a rear power input section along with an on/off switch and cooling fan for Ramps.

The lead screw has been changed to a standard TR8*8.

Additional tie wrap areas have been added to the Extruder Mount and Z Plate.

A List of the modified files are below ( it's basically all of them )

Adoptabot Costs

Adoptabot Github

Adoptabot Remix F360

Printer:

Hexagon

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

Notes:

Printed using Real Filament PETG in Black & Red.

Print Temp : 240°C
Bed Temp : 80°C
Print Speed : 60mm/s

Top Layers : 5
Bottom Layers : 4
Perimeters : 3

Infill : 40%
Remove all Support materials and clean out 3mm holes with a drill bit for easier assembly later on.

Printrbot Design

The original design, idea and everything around this project came from Brook @Printrbot

The Original Adoptabot page can be found here - Printrbot Adoptabot

And the Original F360 files can be found here - Adoptabot F360

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cbQol1Cl1uM" ></iframe>
First Print
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gyj8KFB4tcM" ></iframe>
Fifth Print

These are just the files that have been modified from the original.
  • Y Bar End Back - Thickened slightly to increase stiffness
  • Y Bar End Front - Top Linear Rod now passes straight through with clamp at the end to

remove droop.

  • Extruder Mount - Tie wrap point added.
  • Case 1 Front - Endstop mount modified.
  • Case 2 Rear - Cooling slots and new fixing points.
  • Z Plate - Endstop mount modified, Tie wrap point added and new Integrated nut mount.
  • Z Top Handle - Thickened slightly, bearing added.
  • X Bar End Left - Endstop flag modified.

Hardware List

I have provided a link to my Google Drive file that i put together for the parts i used and their cost.

Adoptabot Costs

Software

As i am using a Ramps 1.5 board the firmware of choice is of course marlin, i Have configured everything for my setup but you may need to tweak it for yours.

The firmware settings i have used i have added to my Github along with everything else.

Adoptabot Github

description.text:
Want to play your Nintendo Switch but don't want to hold it ? I feel you. Play and recharge your console by clipping it to this 7 axis arm. -20 M4L20 screws

-22 M4 nylon stop bolts

-30 D4 washes

author: slowsword

description.text:
PRINT WITH SUPPORTS! Please rotate the print assembly.stl as seen in the photo along with any other extra parts that you may need to be replaced.
A variation of the Dayan Guhong 3 by 3 speedcube. It may not be as smooth as the Dayan but with a little lube or after repeated use it should wear and turn smoothly. There is added tolerance. UNTESTED!! I will test as soon as I have access to a 3d printer (hopefully soon). Please read the instructions for assembly.
Around 8 hours of work. Inspired by my love of Rubik's cubes; I've been solving them since the 6th grade.

FOR ASSEMBLING THE CUBE:
Push the pieces with the round pegs on top into the holes in the sphere. They are similar to a snap fit and need to be popped in (may require excessive force).
The pieces with the poles shooting out of the corners are corner pieces and the others are edge pieces. Fit each piece into it's respective spot on the cube but remember that the last piece that should be pushed in to complete the cube is an edge piece otherwise the corner piece may break.
If you break a piece, don't worry about it; I've included .stl files for each individual piece that you can reprint.
Don't be afraid to comment suggestions, problems, or questions.

comments.text: i just wanted to point out that there are only 4 centre pieces included in the actual print assembly where 6 are needed, one for each side. i am currently printing and will let you know how it goes
comments.author: drednie

remixed_from.author: sirmakesalot
remixed_from.title: Modular hollow universal joint for cable management

description.text:
Hollow universal joint, printable as a single unit & parametric with openscad.
The scad's got a decent amount of comments, I might clean it up and upload a better version later, but it's pretty straightforward.

Print! The joint+ring stl should print well - there's a 1mm gap between the ring and the joint. Be sure to use Brim or some other method to get the part to adhere strongly. Doesn't require any connectors, the pieces just snap together. Idea came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25872, also used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3140 to start the openscad bit, but I went through and parameterized everything. To resize, all you should need to change are the outer_rad and wall parameters - the first is the overall radius (so the part will be twice as wide), the 2nd is the wall thickness. As written, the inner diameter is outer_rad2-(wall2+1).
The part displayed is 20mm outer_rad and 3mm wall, so outside is 40mm around and inside hollow is 33mm.

Finally, a snowman that will hold my phone high enough to see it! I don't know why this problem hasn't been solved sooner!

I printed the body in natural clear pla because I am out of white. I printed the hat in black and the arms in black because I am out of brown. All parts were printed with 20% infill and the body was printed with a brim to prevent it from popping off the bed after a few hours of printing. You know cooling and what-not.

I finished the eyes, nose, scarf, mouth, and buttons with a 3d pen which is fun but difficult. To keep the phone from sliding off I used the pen to make a lip on the hat. Was going to use the natural pla to look like snow but it wasn't working so well in the 3d pen so I used black. I will definitely be doing more 3d pen stuff.

Please Please Please post your makes of these I really like the "little kid art project" look of them. Too much fun!

The 3d pen I have is an RP100A but there are other ones out there

Thanks Jeremy

title: Anet A8 modular axial fan mount adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When my blower broke after 3 months, I did not want to constantly have to buy a new one. So I looked for a possibility that can last longer and use other fans.
Then found this, which corresponded to my first rough idea: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149198.
However, in my opinion, a 80mm fan is too big to mount on the extruder. and I wanted to build something modular, which is also as compact as possible.

The advantages:

  • modular construction
  • very compact and fast to print
  • for fans 60mm and with adapter 40mm
  • level sensor bracket for 18mm sensor with adapter for 12mm sensor
  • with adapter compatible with the fan ducts of the original blower
  • wider connection for fan ducts (40x13mm / standard are 17x13mm)

I have installed the wider connection because the axial fans can not build up pressure. Therefore, I would also recommend the use of the wide fan duct with this adapter. Compatibility with the standard ducts is optional but not meaningful.
The level sensor is here a few millimeters further forward, but is with me with the standard settings at skynet3d compatible. If necessary, please adjust these values!

In principle, the adapter is still in the test phase.
However, if you would like to test it yourself, you are welcome to do so.
I'm happy about feedback and suggestions.

Anet A8

No

Yes

Notes:

Print the "fan sensor mount.stl" with support (to fit the duct hole).
Other parts didnt need support.

description.text:
This is a magnetically mounted frag plug rack for marine aquariums. It was printed in PLA, but I suggest ABS or PETG for the longest life.

Uses 32mm x 2mm rare earth magnets, available from numerous online sources. Mine came from Amazon.

The magnets were coated in aquarium silicone, then glued in their holders. After several days to dry they were coated with multiple coats of black spray-on plasti-dip. For my next build, I'll use the solid plasti-dip and simply dip in the magnets.

I'm hoping that will seal them enough to last, but no promises.

Note: Fits most plugs, but not the 1/2" ones. Holes are 10mm, which is a good fit for most of the plugs I have found. I'm using the Oceans Wonders coral frag plugs in the picture: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06Y6DYQXW

See also my other frag rack: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2672511

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1-2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

In order to get it to print flat, there are some angles from the magnets to the main frame that can use support to look nicer, and the top of the magnet holders as well, so run support on the main print.

Print two Mag holders, and four caps for each unit.

Waterproofing

Be sure to seal the magnets, they WILL rust quickly. I used a layer of silicone sealer, as well as 3-4 coats of spray-on Plasti-dip.

description.text:
This is a magnetically mounted frag plug rack for marine aquariums. It was printed in PLA, but I suggest ABS or PETG for the longest life.

Uses 32mm x 2mm rare earth magnets, available from numerous online sources. Mine came from Amazon.

The magnets were coated in aquarium silicone, then glued in their holders. After several days to dry they were coated with multiple coats of black spray-on plasti-dip. For my next build, I'll use the solid plasti-dip and simply dip in the magnets.

I'm hoping that will seal them enough to last, but no promises.

Note: Fits most plugs, but not the 1/2" ones. Holes are 10mm, which is a good fit for most of the plugs I have found. I'm using the Oceans Wonders coral frag plugs in the picture: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06Y6DYQXW

See also my corner-frag rack: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2672482

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1-2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

In order to get it to print flat, there are some angles from the magnets to the main frame that can use support to look nicer, and the top of the magnet holders as well, so run support on the main print.

Print two Mag holders, and four caps for each unit.
Be sure to seal the magnets, they WILL rust quickly. I used a layer of silicone sealer, as well as 3-4 coats of spray-on Plasti-dip.
I am always buying and selling used camera gear so I need these all the time. When the need comes up I design one!

sarah

description.text:
I wanted to use a micro CCD camera on the X2 Elf so took the Punisher Pod which has two mount holes on the front and one in the back so I was able to scale it down in TinkerCAD to the right dimensions for the X2 Elf frame. Because of the camera screw location the max prop size is now 1940 and not 2035.

It might be possible to move the camera location up above the prop line and then be able to fit 2-inch props but I'm not sure how.

title: Max Micron i3 2020 tall board mount

description.text:
This is a raised mount for the Max Micron 2020 board to lift it up higher on the frame. I was bothered by the wires coming off the bottom of the board and being bent/stressed immediately after leaving the connector and hitting on the table. Think this give them a little more room and less stress making for a longer lasting and safer printer.

will likely work with other boards on a 2020 frame where the lower bed structure is mounted to the inside of the tower structure.

comments.text:
That may be possible if the printer is not perfectly calibrated (because it fits the PCB size exactly without margin).
If the printer is not perfectly calibrated on X and Y, you have to be careful and use same orientation for both part (then, if there is a scaling issue on X or Y, that will be the same on both part and still fit).
I hope it will fit on your printer and I can redesign a specific one for you if I know the scaling issue that may occur on X or Y

description.text:
--- As of January 7th 2017 this design was also introduced in the Liftoff drone racing simulator! See also: http://www.liftoff-game.com/2017/01/07/update-0-8-1-released/ ---

"Aether was designed with the objective of creating an innovative, aesthetically pleasing and compact drone that could be easily and cheaply manufactured with the use of consumer grade CNC-machines such as a 3D-printer. The result is a sleek, 220-sized drone consisting of an exceptionally sturdy 3D-printed shell and a beefy bottom plate in either plywood or carbon fiber.

As Aether is based on my specific, personal preferences, I will freely share the design files in the near future to anyone looking to tweak or customize the design to their own likings. By sharing my designs, I allow pilots to make and build their own real-life versions of the frames!"

Note that this version is a slightly taller version with more space for internal components. The exact Liftoff version has been tested and approved as well, but made it unnecessarily crowded internally.

Also note that the battery strap is supposed to reach around both the pod and the frame.

author: Rogal_Dorn

description.text:
Nevma

A USB gadget to transform your gestures to keyboard and mouse events.

Overview

Nevma (means "gesture" in Greek) is a simple to build, program and use device that translates your hand gestures into keyboard and mouse input. Just plug it in your USB port and magically wave through your presentations, documents, pictures, songs and the like.

How does it work

Nevma implements two basic functions. Gesture recognition and keyboard and mouse event generation over USB. The former is realized through the APDS-9960 sensor while the latter by utilizing the USB HID capabilities of the ATMega32U4 chip.

Nevma can by default recognize a plethora of gestures; swipe left, right, up, down, and moving the hand closer or further from the sensor, using the APDS-9960 library by Sparkfun.

Components

  • Nevma board PCB
  • 3D printed case
  • Mini SS Micro ATMEGA32U4
  • APDS-9960 module

Media

  • Nevma: Gesture control for the masses

Printer:

M3D Micro

description.text:
Nomura, Japan - Spanwijdte 42 cm

Titel: Blikken Vliegtuig Lockheed Electra L-188 KLM PH-DSF
Fabrikant: Nomura
Jaar: 1965
Voorwerp: Vliegtuig
Materiaal: Blik, Kunststof
Thema: Luchtvaart
Land: Japan
Afmetingen: 42 cm x 39.5 cm
Bijzonderheden: Bovenkant geheel van blik, onderkant van hard plastic. Grote wielen van rubber, neuswielen van hard plastic, cockpit- en zijraampjes van doorzichtig plastic. Het vliegtuig loopt op 2 x 1.5 volt batterijen en in de 'on' stand gaan de propellers draaien, rijdt het vooruit terwijl het licht in de cockpit en in het achterste deel van de cabine aan gaat. Japanse fabrikanten lieten op verzoek van importeurs vaak het merkteken weg, omdat speelgoed bijv. door de HEMA, of in het buitenland door Marks&Spencer, werd verkocht en van een eigen merksticker voorzien. De registratiekenmerken, in dit geval PH-DSF, werden door speelgoedfabrikanten niet consequent en voor verschillende modellen gebruikt.* Het jaar van productie (1965) is een schatting, gebaseerd op analoge Lockheed Electra modellen van Japanse fabrikanten.* De KLM was de enige Europese carrier die met de Lockheed Electra als lange-afstandsvliegtuig vloog. Andere waren: American Airlines, Eastern Air Lines en Braniff Airways (nl.wikipedia.org). Boot, Rob. Persoonlijke mededeling, CATAWIKI, 03062014. **Marchand, Frédéric. Avions-Jouets 1945-1970. Paris: Éditions Langlaude, 2004.

print_settings.Notes:: Model units are in inches.

description.text:
This is based off ccrumpacker's Kerfmaker, but I've remodeled it to be able to accommodate a full kerf from a 7/8" dado stack. I also made a few tweaks to tolerances of the sliding components along with improving the knurling and accessibility of the two knobs. Maximum allowable stock is right around 3".

Simple half-lap setup: https://stusshed.com/tag/km-1/
Video tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PQ6_S6lZKLI

Remodeling was done from scratch in solidworks and I've included the assembly/part files as well as the .STL files for printing. Model units are in inches make sure your .stl units are set correctly otherwise the imported parts will be very small.

Print quantities:
2 - knob.STL
1 - top.STL
1 - middle.STL
1 - bottom.STL

Additional hardware required (note I used McMaster for ease of modeling, but you can find this metric hardware at a local hardware store) Also, yes, the hardware is metric but the print is standard. It's the world we live in:

2 - M5 bolts, 20mm long
https://www.mcmaster.com/#91310a124/=1afvdvs

2 - M5 nuts
https://www.mcmaster.com/#98676a300/=1afvg2x

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

Dimension SST 1200es

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.010"

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Model units are in inches.

Dimension highlighted is 0.88" - the offset between the two highlighted planes is what you use to set your kerf to your saw blade. Section view through the middle of the model showing hardware locations. After setting the kerf of your blade, measure the width of your stock that you're making a dado or groove for. Bring your fence against the tool in both orientations to cut both sides of the cut. On the left I'm measuring a random 1x2. The kerf has already been set for a flat-top ground 1/8" blade. On the right is the slot cut for the stock. That's the surface finish straight off the saw! Here's the direct fit.

This is my first print off the da Vinci Color beta unit. It was only fitting that the first print off the machine named after Leonardo da Vinci be his most famous painting. It is a little bit blurry but that mostly has to do with the lighting.

The da Vinci Color is the first 2d inkjet FDM 3D printer. The machine uses CMYK ink and special ink absorbing PLA. The da Vinci Color works by accepting an obj with its mtl file. It prints the physical layer first then it prints the ink over that layer.

title: Compact Pro 4th Axis Stabilizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The dreaded 'gimbal bob' will be a thing of the past with the silky smooth footage you'll get with the new Compact Pro Model 4th Axis Camera Stabilizer in single and dual handle!

  • Completely Tool-less adjustments - make changes in seconds
  • Adjustable Fluid Damping - from hard action to soft shots
  • Load Adjuster to adapt to your rig
  • Adjust in seconds from upright to mid height to briefcase mode
  • Get buttery smooth footage from compact cameras!
  • Only 23 Ounces (650grams) or for the dual handle it's 2.4 pounds (1.1kg)
  • The dual handle also has a built in stand.

This build has some parts that are tricky to print as well as hard to get parts such as bearings, damping gel, springs and nuts and bolts. I've put together two DIY parts kits for sale on my website; https://scottymakesstuff.com/ to make the process super easy for you.
One of the parts kit is for the single handle stabilizer and the other also adds the double handle stabilizer and stand.

Here's all the YouTube videos covering these stabilizers:-
Features:- https://youtu.be/smD-RTGe4J4
Showreel:- https://youtu.be/YJ4jBCNqeLs
DIY Assembly:- https://youtu.be/rivhUJsmm-I
Change the Spring:- https://youtu.be/gBHZEe3udI8

I've also made an adaptor to fit the DJI Osmo to this stabilizer here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2721489

The cameras in today's phones, action cams and small mirrorless systems can produce stunning footage. Add a compact gimbal and you come close to footage seen on much more expensive systems at a small fraction of the price.

But the one big detractor when taking moving shots with gimbals is the dreaded gimbal bob that can spoil what could otherwise be great footage. This bobbing motion can be minimised with the skill of the camera operator but on uneven ground or on longer takes you’ll find that without some form of 4th axis stabilization you’ll have z motion artifacts creeping into your footage.

My primary goal when designing the new Compact Pro Stabilizer was to achieve buttery smooth footage when shooting on gimbals with anything from gentle movement all the way to running full pace. And all this while being more Pro friendly.

The current crop of compact Z or 4th Axis stabilizers only work well at a normal smooth walking pace and develop a harmonic bounce when speeding up or when slowing down. Essentially, they balance but they don’t really dampen the bounce.

My already developed variable fluid damping cartridges in the full sized Pro 1 model solved this bounce but I wanted to make it even better.

So after extensive product development and testing I’m extremely proud to introduce the new Pro Model Compact 4th Axis Stabilizer.

The new design is a finely tuned piece of camera kit that glides effortlessly on 9 high quality bearings, it removes bounce with a new high-tech variable fluid damping cartridge and the geometry has been further optimised to give the best possible 4th axis motion reduction. I’m seriously chuffed at how good it works - it’s a major improvement in compact camera z axis stabilization! If you’re a content creator then this should definitely be in your kit bag.

The adjustable fluid damping inherited from the full size Pro 1 has been further improved with the addition of highly specialised synthetic shock absorbing fluid that can quickly adjust to take you from the softest motion to those running like crazy to keep up with your talent shots!

This kit include the two different payload adjustment springs - the 375 spring which suits more typical compact gimbal and camera rigs weighing from 7 ounces to 2 pounds (200g to 900g) and for heavier payloads the 371 spring goes from 1 to 3.8 pounds (500g to 1.7kg).

For pro use I wanted to be able to quickly change my rig on the go between shots with tool-less adjustments and when the shoot was over I wanted it to pack down small. I also wanted to expand the range of uses with modular add-ons such as a handle that takes the Zhiyun Remote Control.

The Compact Pro Kit has dual adjustable grips with a built in stand so you can put your stabilizer down between takes - if you’ve ever held a fully rigged Ronan up for any more than a few minutes you’ll know how much you wished for a built in stand to rest your arms! The kit also comes with all the necessary tools for changing springs or for fine tuning.

I’m unapologetically excited about this Compact Pro Stabilizer Kit as there’s nothing else out that stabilizes close to as well in as many different types of scenarios as this does. Now, I’m no pro camera operator by any stretch of the imagination and even with a dodgy knee I can get great results. I can’t wait to see what you guys produce with it!

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

You can see all my videos on my YouTube Channel, ScottyMakesStuff here:-
https://www.youtube.com/c/ScottyMakesStuff
https://twitter.com/ScottyMakesStuf
https://www.instagram.com/scottymakesstuff/

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Notes:

To start, there are a lot of parts and each has specific instruction listed below. I suggest printing models in the orientation supplied. As this is a model that uses close tolerances (less than 0.2mm) your printer will have to be calibrated correctly or you'll have problems.

I use the triangular infill as it's good and strong. With my printers running at normal speeds and Simplify3D slicing I find all parts need little to no post printing work and fit perfectly... don't rush it! I print mine in an improved PLA. This is good to 55C (130F) degrees so don't leave it in a car on a very hot day... but the same should be said of any camera equipment so I think improved PLA will be best for 95% of you. You can try other filaments such as PETG, ABS or PC but you'd want to have a special set up and be a pro at getting those to work flawlessly.

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly.

GimbalSupport

Settings: 0.20mm layers, 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports,

SpringAdjust

Settings: 0.08mm - 0.20mm layers (see below), 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly. In that case I'd suggest printing all but the rosette at 0.20mm to 0.30mm and printing just the rosette at 0.08mm.

Handles

Settings: 0.10 - 0.3mm layers (see below), 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports, has a captured nut in each handle base

I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to the rosette I change the layer height to 0.10mm and then back to 0.3mm after 2mm of printing the rosette

The handles have captured bolts that will need to be inserted during the print. You can make sure you're there to pause the print and drop the nuts in or you could get a little funky with some gcode to stop the print for you. I typically use the free notepad++ to add some simple code to the gcode file just right before the covering layer is printed. Your printer will wait at this point until you hit resume. This is some example code (Note: please add X & Y coordinates to suit your print so that the print head gets out of the way for you) ;
; layer (whatever layer your print comes to), Z = 9.6 (depending on your print layer height the handle will need to be about this height when it stops)
; Add Nuts
M117 Add the nuts Scotty ; displays the message on your printer
G1 X(add your X coord here) Y(add your Y coord here) F8000 ; move out of way - you will need to work yours out relative to your print
M72 @pause ; pauses and plays the pause tune
M0
; inner perimeter

Alternatively the 'M600' change filament command works on many Marlin run printers. It's simple as all you need to add is a line with 'M600' in it and will often move the print head out of the way (depending on your printer). The only downside is that you will need to load the filament again.

I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to the rosette I change the layer height to 0.10mm and then back to 0.3mm after 2mm of printing the rosette

SpringKnob, GimbalScrewKnob, DampeningKnob & HandleKnob

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, No Supports

Note: These comes in the DIY pack already attached to bolts and nuts

TopArm and BottomArm

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3-4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

DamperDynamicSide & DamperStaticSide

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

The dynamic side will also need to be thread tapped with a 6mm tap. You cam use a 6mm bolt but the end result isn't as easy to turn.
Note: This comes in the DIY pack already tapped and pre filled with high tech damping gel

Crossbar

Settings: 0.10 to 0.30 mm layers , 3-4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to the rosette I change the layer height to 0.10mm and then back to 0.3mm after 2mm of printing the 2 rosettes. The third rosette will print ok at 0.3mm as it's oriented vertically

From my first prototype till the Pro 1 I used heavy greases. I tried around 10 in total... mostly the more expensive and thickest varieties.
I would put at least half of the smoothing performance increase (from Pro 1 to Pro 2) down to the high quality damping gel. The fluid dynamics of the damping gel is quite different to any grease you'll buy in a store. You can use a very heavy grease but you won't get the best smoothing performance.

Bobblejot Website

Bobblejot GitHub

Bobblejot Twitter

i needed some additional storage space so knocked up these quick parts to create a modular filament rack using easily available 19mm tubing from most hardware shops.

description.text: This is a means to securely mount a 5015 radial fan onto a 30mm heat sink with 25 x 25 mm M3 screw holes. A radial will kill heat creep in the heat sink and keep your cold end COLD.

comments.text: I have been having issues where my dual nozzles have been jamming, and I believe heat creep is the issue. When I use both nozzles at 200 degrees at the same time, the heatsink feels so hot that I can't touch it without burning myself. Will this upgrade solve my issue?
comments.author: Bobertjr85

comments.text: Bobert, I believe it will do the trick, but if it struggles, I suggest filing some of the plastic material around the corners near the screw mounts to expose more aluminum.  Doing that will increase air flow a bit more.  Generally speaking though, radial fans generate much more static pressure and will force a larger volume of air across the fins and whisk away more heat.

description.text:
Mod for TPU printing with the Anycubic I3 Mega.

The hole for the bowden ist bigger than the original mod.

Update2:

I changed the mod a little bit, so that the top ist more between the two wheels.
The difference between the two versions ist the size of the hole.

v1: Holediamter 2,0mm (for Saintsmart TPU 1,75mm, but Filmanet is ca. 1,65mm)

v2: Holediameter 2,2mm (for other Flex/TPU Filament)

I know that the default diameter of filament is 1,75mm, but with a 0,4mm nozzle its not exact printable. The easiest way is to print both version an try in wich one the filament fit preferably.

Update1:

I used the mod also when i print PLA and ABS, but after some time there was a squeaking at the extruder. So i changed back to the original one and use the mod only when i want to print TPU.

Hello, (german decription below)

this thing is an clip to put an adapter in. The adapter has to be an USB-Mirco to USB-Typ C.
This Thing can hold the adapter near the end of a micro-USB-cable. So it can be used as an micro or (with plugged the adapter between the connectors) a USB type C cable. The adapter is protected from get lost.

It´s printed by using flexible material (Flexismart) and fitts very strongly on the adapter.
Printersettings were: 0.15 layer height with 100% infill. No support needed, because there are no overhangs.

Please feel free to print it and use it. I would like to see your makes.

Enjoy it...

title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Blower Fanmount with modular Duct for Dual extruder with BLTouch support

description.text:
Here's my version of the Tevo Tarantula Dual Extruder Dual Blower fanmount with BLTouch Support.

Install Steps:

  1. print mount
  2. print one duct
  3. assemble mount, duct and one fan to the hotend
  4. print another duct
  5. assemble second fan and second duct
    5a. print two fresh ducts (for quality reasons) and scrap the first ones
  6. print the fan mounts (2xside - one used to be mirrored in cura, and 1xtop)
  7. assemble everything using M3 screws, nuts and washers.

Notes:
The airholes of the duct are a bit small - maybe I'll update this later.
For now I used a diamondfile to widen the holes a bit for better airflow.
If some parts are a bit to thight to put together (for ex the ducts to assemble on the mount) use a diamondfile to make them fit perfectly.

I have found (after printing 10 of them!) that the 20mm XYZ cube does not provide the required accuracy for a calibration. With a deviation from 0.1mm to 20mm you may get a deviation of 1mm in maximum on a 200mm object. My XYZ cubes were calibrated to 20.05mm x 20.04mm x 20.02mm. But after printing a 150x150x10mm rectangular with the calibrated values I got this: 151x150.9x9.98mm

So I created this 150mmx150mm calibration cross.
After printing, let it cool down to room temperature. Then measure the axis. But put the cross on the table, because the axis are very thin and flexible (to save filament and printing time).

description.text:
This is a cover to fill the opening in the back of hte TEVO Black Widow where the cables come out. It is not really necessary, but I think it looks nicer and tidier with the cover installed.

I made it as an exercise in Fusion 360 and also in printing. There are two versions; the Full version will fill the entire opening (18mm x 70mm) while the shorter version (18mm x 55mm) will fit if you have a USB port adapter installed like I do (as long as it is also in the same size, of course).

I installed it from the inside to get a flush finish on the outside.

Removed the supports, and I also had to file the edges and connections a little bit to make it fit. In the current version I have made the dimension of the inserted part .5mm smaller in both directions to make it fit easier. The problem I had initially could be related to slight over-extrusion.

I measured the dimensions of the opening where the cables came out as well as the dimension of the tubes with the cables (I have them in three bundles). From there it was pretty straightforward to make it in Fusion 360.

I made two versions, because I started the design before I installed the USB connector, but I needed a smaller one now since the connector takes up some space.

--- Work in progress ----

I'm currently experimenting to find a good esk8 enclosure to fit the components i'm using. If you have any tips, I would gladly appreciate a comment :)

PocketQub (pronounced "Pocket-Cube") is a new small satellite.  Much like the CubeSat, a 10cm-cube satellite, the PocketQub is a 5cm-cube satellite.  Unlike CubeSats, PocketQubs still don't have a solid standard for their form factor and deployment systems into space.  Keeping that in mine, here is my attempt of a PocketQub structure design.   
Inside would stack 1) a small LiPo battery, 2) a battery charger board, 3) 3.3V DC/DC and solar panel interface board, 4) The processor board, and 5) the communications board.

Base plate for my ED209 model. I made it out of aluminum on a EOS M280. The ED209 model I cannot take credit for as much as I wish I could. I did build it in m machine but I did not create the model. It took me almost 3 months running parts when I could. It was a solid model that I cut into sections so i could run each of them when i had time and space. I painted it with a car primer and then added the details in. Looks decent for my painting abilities.

I found a picture of the OCP logo and laid it in SpaceClaim as an overlay. I outlined the part and extruded the faces as needed. Once it was built, I milled the back and the front to a smooth surface. Sanded the surface up to a 1000 grit and then polished it on our buffing wheel. Finished it off with some Mothers Mag polish and it shines very well for aluminum.

print_settings.Notes:: I suggest using layer editing to increase the resolution in areas where the surfaces is flatter. For example, the top of totodile's head.

description.text: I remixed sch00f's chess with with low poly pokemons for easier printing. The pieces are arranged by height so pawn is the shortest, and king is the tallest, etc...No support needed, although Lapras could use some support on the fins for nicer prints. Each base will take 4x M8 nuts for the perfect weight.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support is recommended for Lapras only. Best to use support from build plate only.

I suggest using layer editing to increase the resolution in areas where the surfaces is flatter. For example, the top of totodile's head.

Insert nuts

Apply super glue to bottom and 1 side of the nut, and drop it into the base. Tap on the baset to make sure the side of the nut with the glue touches the inside wall. Continue to do this for 3 more nuts, totaling to 4 nuts per base. The nuts can be M8 or 5/16 inch. Continue with the rest of the pieces the glue can cure. After a few minutes, you may go back to the first piece, and turn it upside down, and shake and tap rigorously, attempting to shake the nuts loose. If there is not rattle, you can move onto next step, if you hear any rattle, then force the nut out and apply more glue. The mentality is if it rattles now, it will for sure come loose with play, and by then, you won't be able to fix the rattle.

Glue the pokemon onto the base

Once the nuts are rattle-free, you may glue the pokemon onto the weighted base. Make sure you orient the button of the pokeball towards the front, and that the shape of the base matches the shape of the pokemon (circle to circle, pentagon to pentagon, etc...)
Apply the glue onto the base on top of the pokeball, surrounding the hexagon shape. See below red circles. Do not apply the glue on the pokemon as it may prematurely glue itself onto other surfaces when you try to assemble it.

description.text:
Superdetailed, probably many features are unprintable on your printer in sufficient small scaling. Naming scheme

  • The parts are named from players: "a" exists, "b" does not, and should be mirrored, and printed in a different color (only applies to few pieces, as many are symmetric).
    Then the number indicates the ID, and the x? indicates how often it should be printed.

    • The C-shaped part "8" needs some expansion, so other parts can be fit into. this is done my deforming the stl, hence a8shrunk is better printed instead of a8x1. Trivia

  • I did not plate, because the files would be too large.

UPDATE 1/82016 - Added Step-by-Step Build Instructions PDF file and another pic. Hope this can help!
UPDATE 1/6/2018 - Added Assembly Instruction Video #3 and Updated BOM Screw Count

MicroRAP 100 is a compact desktop 3D Printer. When designing this printer, my main goal was to minimize desktop footprint, while still maintaining a respectable print build envelope of 100mm x 100mm x 100mm. Also, because of the small size, the plywood frame can be easily cut using many smaller, homemade CNC mills such as the MPCNC and Root2CNC. Use 1/4" or 6mm wood. Everything wooden in the design can be cut with a 1/8" straight endmill. Laser cutting will also work great.
The print results are excellent. It uses the E3D v6, E3D lite6, or chinese v6 clone type hotends. The build surface is a made from a small chunk of acrylic with 3 holes drilled in it with painters tape placed on top (or whatever material you'd like). Optionally, you can use the BLTouch to G29 autolevel it.
The files included are an improved version of what you see in the pictures and it now uses a series of printed connectors and m3 nuts/screws to secure the frame.
Complete and itemized bill of materials is included in the files (down to every last screw needed!)
I've used this printer for a build-your-own 3d printer class at yakimamakerspace.org
There are some assembly instructional videos but so far I've only finished the first three;
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vFLvEt0uwdI&t=14s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NHWm2s4ASvs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CqHEd3FNkzA

Thanks for giving it a try!

comments.text: I've built printers using 2020 aluminum extrusions and I believe that they aren't really that solid of a design. The main advantage of such frames is that they can be built without access to a cnc machine or laser cutter. Perhaps the linear motion system of those printers could be better, but as far as the chassis goes, I don't see any advantage to a 2020 frame that is only connected at the edges (Except that it can be made without a CNC/Laser). description.text: Water

Enjoy! 0 Shells 100% Fill This will work better if you spray it with acetone or dip it in acetone you should heat first so it doesn't get hazy do to moisture being trapped from the cooling acetone and humid air. You can dip ABS parts or spray ABS parts but they will typically Hayes if you use acetone this can be avoided by heating before and after The quickly evaporating acetone makes it cold which causes water to condense and creates a haze on your parts very undesirable heat or very dry atmosphere prevents this also you can buy clear ABS glue from a plastic supply store Weldon 2354
secondly you can chase the threads with a metal hose fitting and I even have one that I've cut notches and so it's like a metal pipe threading tap. MEK makes a much better solvent but you can't buy it in California anymore. 38 million people I guess you have to have Nannys. And obviously you'll need a rubber hose washer. I have ones I've been using for over three years left outdoors but the one I think is really cool is the fan spray nozzle on a different page

title: Anet A8 LASER Bracket - Rear Mount - v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As advertised, here is Version 2 of my bracket.
Now, the fan holder and the holes to fix the laser were moved about 6,1 mm to the left.
So, now the carriage will reach the endstop (in default position) of the x-axis.

Information:
I used CROSSJOIN's well designed Sensor Mount as base for my Laser Mount for the Laser module of the Neje Laser engraver.
Above the Laser module I added a holder for 40x40 mm fans for cooling.
The laser is fixed by two M3 screws from behind.

The bracket should be attached behind the carriage.
I use it by myself with this design - it should work out of the box for u too.

Following only applies to Version 1:
!!! IMPORTANT !!!

Because of the fan holder, the carriage will not reach the Endstop (if the endstop is on "default" position) of the X-Axis. So, you have to move it some mm to the right e.q. or put something on the carriage to hit the end stop.
Further, the carriage will now be in end-position, earlier as before. So you should adjust the "Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)" for the X_MIN_POS in your firmware.

Please use version 2 if you haven't if you have no good reason to use version 1 ;)

description.text:
Updated 11/30/17, made the top taller and the inside different.

This is a two part case for the DJI Mavic Pro. I made two versions, one that has slots for 1 inch Velcro straps and one that does not use straps. The tops are the same for either.

I really like the shape of the case by Sebastian_De which is the source of this remix but decided on a different approach.

This design uses the same overall shape but split it horizontally and uses a combination friction and snap fit to hold together the top and bottom. To open, you squeeze the depressions on either side to flex the sides and release the locking tab. The extended lip on the bottom is at a 6 degree draft to mate with the recess on the top.

I have printed a prototype that works and have loaded the photos of the red and blue parts.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium or fast

Infill:

20%

Notes:

3 shells, PLA

You will want to put some sort of cushioning inside the case to protect the drone from getting banged up and holding it tight.

This cushioning could range from bubble wrap to foam rubber, it is up to you. I have not done my cushioning yet, but would refer to the source design that I remixed from for guidance.

Bottom with suggested padding pieces Top with suggested padding pieces--the open areas are so the foam does not press on the top props.

Do not carry strapless version of this case by just holding the top with the case hanging down as it could pop open. You don't want to risk treating your $1,000 drone to the results of a drop.

If you are concerned about it popping open during transportation or handling, you can always get some Velcro tape or a large elastic band as added insurance and use either bottom
